@Joe_Stephens Interested in learning more from @Joe_Stephens on what it means to be a responsible consumer of media in this moment? ‚§µÔ∏è https://t.co/hcXtjYIFpV

@Joe_Stephens 5Ô∏è‚É£: Include ‚Äòiron core‚Äô stories in your media diet.
 
"Like a game of telephone, the farther you get from the original account, the less reliable it becomes,‚Äù says @Joe_Stephens ‚Äî so look to the news reported firsthand by news organizations, facts checked & presented in context.

@Joe_Stephens 4‚É£: Pay attention: Learn to distinguish between journalism and everything else.
 
Ask questions around sources, direct observation, and documents/data.
 
What human sources were used?

Does the story include direct observation, or is it hearsay?

What data is used to back it up?

2Ô∏è‚É£: Exercise your rights as a responsible media consumer.

Decide what information you put in your head.

‚ÄúAsk yourself: Who produced it and why? ... And is someone, somewhere along the food chain, working to verify the facts?‚Äù says @Joe_Stephens.

1Ô∏è‚É£: Keep a media diary for 48 hours. üìù

Write down absolutely everything you consume, then consider:

üì∫ What medium is it?
 üó£Ô∏è What source does it come from?
 ‚ÄºÔ∏è Is it breaking news or in-depth analysis?
 
Take a deep analysis and contemplate whether any changes are in order.

Learn how to be a responsible media consumer with these 6Ô∏è‚É£ tips from #PrincetonU journalism professor @Joe_Stephens.
